United States Department of State / Foreign relations of the United States : diplomatic papers, 1945. General : the United Nations
			(1945)

 The United Nations conference on international organization, San Francisco, California, April 25-June 26, 1945, pp. 1-1432
			
 PDF (565.5 MB) 



Page 906


FOREIGN RELATIONS, 1945, VOLUME 1
 Then TaE SECuTARY asked what time the Big Five meeting should
be held. MR. ARMSTRONG urged that no invitations be issued until
after the meeting -of the Delegation.
 TaEs 'StCRMARY urged again that the members remember the re-
quest for secrecy regarding the deliberations undertaken in this moet-
ing. He requested that the Delegation be able to have a private
discussion without the results of that discussion appearing in-the news-
papers. No background material could be given to the pres, he said.
MR. STvIrxsoN asked whether this should apply to the tioamactions
of the entire meeting. At the start of the meeting, he pointed out,
the Delegation had discussed Committee meeing of the previous
evening and the newsptaper people were certain to know of these Com-
mittee meetings and would press for infornation.-: THi SECRiETARY
reiterated that there should be no comment whatsoever on anything
that had occurred in this meeting. COMMANDER STASSEN stated that
if a draft were to leak- out, he was going to say that no position had
been taken. MR. PASVOLsty remarked that that was the factual sittu-
tion-no position had been taken.
 RESPECT FOR TRmATS
 MR. ROCvEFELLER asked that the Delegation consider a problem
which was going to arise in the 10: 30 meeting of his Conunittee.'7 The
question as to whether a provision concerning respect for treaties
shoul1,be included in the Chapter on Principles or in the Preamble,
was going to be voted on at 10:30. MR. PAsvoLsKY observed that
it had been agreed in the Committee of Five that the words "respect
for treaties" should appear in the Preamble. THE SECRETARY asked
what difference it would make--if the proposal were to appear in
the Preamble, why was there insistence that it should appear in the
Principles f
 U.~2ROOKF^FELEU replied that the problem arose because of the legal
interpretation that the incorporation of the proposal in the Preamble
would not bending. DEAN GILDERSLEzvE reported that the Latin
Americans were pressing for inclusion of this provision in the Chap-
ter on Principles, and THE SECRETARY, sked what opposition there
was to the acceptance of such a position,,, Mn. DuLLEs replied that if
this provision were included in the Principles, the United States
would be bound to respect all treaties. SENATOR VAND"NIwBRG asked
whether the United Stsate did not have the intention of respecting
all treaties. M. DULES asked, in return, whether this country was
 Subcommittee I/I/A agreed at its tenth meeting, May 26, 10: 30 a. m.,
Without di~seut, to the ihflusion in the Charter of a statement on "respect
for
treaties"; the decision whether the statement should be included ini
the pre-
amble or the body of the Charter was to be taken up at the next meeting (US
1/1/A Doe. 10, May 26, not printed).
